from the youth in our Upward Bound, and Job
Corps programs. We have learned that we can
do more. We know now that in spite of our¬
selves, we still form critical value judge¬
ments about individual children, and that this
is damaging because it serves only to reinforce
the "failure syndrome" in them. Through
television, we can help our staff "see themselves"
in those situations.
Experiences with the media have proven conclusively
that many things are possible to achieve. One of
the most important is that through the television
experience, we can mirror an individual's pattern
of failure, lead him to an understanding that those
failures are not "uniquely" his own, show him that
others fail the same way. Then, we can take him
the next, critical step, we can help him experience
success, by showing him the achievement of success
of others. Television can provide the opportunity
to "live through" failure to success, by encouraging
the child to identify with the successful experiences
of others who, like him, have failed. The child,
